OK, some words about the
formalities of the subject.

First of all, the format of
the class is unusual. We meet four hours a week, but
because most if not all of you

are graduate students anxious
to get some work done in the laboratory, we do this in
two two-hour chunks.

So we meet Tuesday and Thursdays

enjoy what's left of the

lingering summer for

time chunk every day of the week

complained about it.

There are a number of
books that deal with

crystallography. For the most part, though,
they consists of an

introductory chapter. Every single book on the solid
state feels compelled to write

some sort of half baked chapter

And usually, these chapters

There are 17 of these. There are 32 of these. There are like 230 of these.

hard to see the plot. So what we will do all the way

So you can not only see how it
turns out, but why it has to be that way.

And that's the way, in my
opinion, one really learns this material.

We will do something

the complexity and

where it comes from. OK, so my moral here
